I recently conducted a study for my PGCE (teacher training) into the usefulness of learning objectives and the results were astonishing.  None of the students could recall any of the objectives from the lesson they had just been involved in moments earlier, despite these being given and on some occasions mentioned throughout the session.  The teachers admitted that the use of SMART learning objectives is a box ticking exercise.  This was a Uni project, on a small scale and I only have a very small amount of experience in teaching being a trainee but the literature review shows that I am not the only one to question this method of target setting.Obviously we all have aims and objectives but sometimes these are not â€˜measurableâ€™, also who are we to tell students what their objectives should be?  Letâ€™s tell them, in our own words (not those prescribed by a system of SMART targets developed for use in business) what OUR objectives are and then let them decide what theirs are â€“ maybe then they would really engage with their learning and take responsibility for it.
Not sure that this is an either/or proposition.
